newsitem.title: USA: INSIGHT - U.S. debt futures seen extending gains.
newsitem.headline: INSIGHT - U.S. debt futures seen extending gains.

text.p: U.S. debt futures are expected to extend Thursday's gains in the next several sessions, particularly if June T-bonds close above the 20-day moving average of 107-22/32, technical analysts said.
Terence Gabriel, a technical analyst at IDEA Inc, said a close above 107-22/32 would be the first time June bonds closed above their 20-day moving average since February 26.

He said the negative momentum of the contract's moving average, which has been forming a negative slope on the charts, has been slowing. He said the moving average has been rising after hitting its lowest level in mid-March.
"The rate of decline has been slowing down," he said.

On Thursday, June T-bonds steadily inched up to 108-07/32, near resistance at 108-08/32, on short-covering pressure. Short-covering was sparked Thursday morning by U.S. weekly jobless claims, which rose to 332,000 from the prior week's upward revised 324,000, and compared with average trade forecasts for 317,000.

However, some analysts said the stage for the market's rally was set on Wednesday when June bonds managed to creep up towards 107-17/32 despite stronger than expected monthly gains in industrial production.
But on Thursday, June T-bonds finally cracked the 2-1/2 week high of 107-28/32, which also represents the weekly Gann resistance level, Gabriel said.

Both bond and Eurodollar futures showed constructive internal factors in the last several days, such as positive daily stochastics. Weekly stochastics for September Eurodollars were particularly oversold.
Like June bonds, September Eurodollars rallied out of their 2-1/2 week range.
September rose to 93.775, above the March 27 high of 93.77 which had confined the contract for the last 2-1/2 weeks.

Gabriel also noted that September held above 93.63, a trendline measurement from July 1996, when the market sold off sharply last week. The contract set a daily low of 93.64 on last Friday, Monday and Tuesday.
Resistance for the contract is at 93.89 and 93.92, the 200-day moving average.

Several analysts are looking for June T-bonds to rise to 108-24/32 to 109-00 in the near term, but said the contract would have to rise above 109-16/32 to turn the medium-term trend positive. ((Derivatives desk 312-408-8750))
